editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A TRUE COPY OF A Popiſh VVill Made in the xixth. Year of King Henry the Eighth, &c.
The Original whereof, with the Probate, may be ſeen at the Sign of the Bull in the Mint, Southwark, in the Cuſtody of Mr. Merrial; and publiſhed onely to ſet forth the Ignorance of the Papiſts.
div.opener: IN the Name of God Amen.
div.p:
The xxiijth. day of the moneth of April, the year of our Lord God M. CCCCC. xxvij. And the xixth. year of the Reign of King Herry, the viijth. I Thomas Cony Citizein and Fletcher of Lond. beying of good and perfyte memory thanked be Almighty God, make, ordeyn, and diſpoſe this my preſent Teſtament and laſt Will in manner and fonrme following, that is, to wite. Firſt, I bequethe and recommend my Soul to Almighty God my Maker and Savyour, and to the glorious and bleſſed Virgyn our Lady Saint Mary, and to alle the holy company of Heavyn, and my Body to be Buryed within the Chirche of Saint Benet Graſ-Church of London, where as I am Pariſhioner in or ny the place where as the Body of Agnes late my Wif now lieth Buryed. Itm, I bequethe to the High Awter of the ſame Chirche for my Tythes
and Oblations forgotten or negligently withholden in diſchargeing of my Conſcience, ii s. Itm, I bequethe to the Fraternitie of our bliſſed Lady in the ſaid Chirche Founded iii s. iiii d. Item, I bequethe, to Margaret my Daughter to hyr to be delyvered whan ſhe ſhall come to her lawful Age or Marriage xx l. Itm, I bequethe to the ſame Margaret my ſtonding Cup of Syluer and on' gilt with a Cover and a Gote ſtonding upon the Top thereof. Itm', I bequeathe to Iohane my Daughter, to hyr to be deliver'd whan ſhe ſhall come to her Lawful Age or Marriage xx l. And oon' Goblet with a Cover gilt with a Roſe on the Top. And if it fortune, as God defend that any of my ſaid Daughters before ſhe ſhall come to hyr Lawful Age or Marriage happen to dy; than I will that the part of hyr that ſo diſceaſeth remayne to the other of them, than beyng alyve, and ſo of either of them, except x l. parcel of the ſaid bequeſte of x l. I will that myn' Erecutours underwritten, or the Executours of any of them, provide and ordein an honeſt preeſt of good Name and Fame to ſyng and ſay Maſſe within the ſaid Chirche of Saint Benet for my Soul, my Fader and Moder Soules, my Wifs Soules, my Freends Soules, my Children Soules, and alle Chriſten Soules by the ſpace of oon year, &c. And than I bequethe to the ſame Preeſt for the ſaid oon year, &c. the ſaid x l. parcel of the ſaid Bequeſts of x l. by me to my ſaid ii. Daughters bequeathen. And alſo I will that the ſame Preeſt ſhall be reſident at all Diuine Service to be ſaid and ſongen within the ſaid Chirche duryng the ſaid Yere, &c. Except that myn Executors command hym' to go to Weſtm' Savoy or Croſſed Freres in London, where he ſhall ſay Maſs for my Soule, and the Soules aforeſaid, as often as myn' Erecutors ſhall appoint hym' thereto, duryng the ſaid Year, &c. Alſo I bequethe to Margaret my Wif all that myn' Intereſt, Title, Right and Termes of Yeres which I have of, and and in all that my Tenement that I now dwell in, which I hold by a Leas of the graunt of James Walſingham and Edmond his Son for certeyn termes of Yeres, to have and to hold all the ſaid intereſt and termes of Yeres to the ſaid Margaret, to hir Executors and Aſſignes duryng the Yeres now for to come, of and in the ſame. And furthermore, I will that of the Iſſues and Profits that ſhall Yerely come and growe of and in all my ſaid Tenements that I now dwell in the ſame, Margaret my Wif ſhall kepe or cauſe to be kept an Yearly Obite or Anniverſary within the ſaid Chirche of Saint B ••••… , for my Soule and the Soules aforeſaid, expending every Yere Yerely at the ſaid Obite duryng the ſpace of vij Yeres next enſuing my diſceas xiij s. and iv d. in manner and fourme following, that is to ſay, to vi. poor Houſholders of the ſaid Pariſh of Saint Bennet, vi s. that is to wite, to every of them xij d. ſo that the ſame vi Houſholders be at my Dirige and Maſs, requiring them to pray for my Soule and the Soules aforeſaid, vij s. and iiij d. reſidues of the ſaid Somme of xiij s. iiij d. to be ſpent and given amongeſt Preeſts and Clerks of the ſaid Chirche and for Rynging of
Bells and other Obſequies to ſuche an Obite accuſtomed, and amongeſt the Pariſhioners for Brede, Drink and Cheſe; and whan and eſſoone as the ſaid vij Yeres ſhall be complete and full ronne, than I will that every Yere Yerely, duryng and aſlong as any intereſt and termes of Yeres that ſhall be than for to come of and in the ſame Tenement, after that the ſaid vij Yeres be full ronne, myn' Obite to be kept within the ſaid Chirche of Saint Bennet, for my Soule and the Soules aforeſaid, expending of the ſaid Iſſues and Profits that ſhall Yerely come of and in the ſame Tenements, but oonly vi s. iiij d. Itm' I bequethe to William Cony my Broder the Rom of the Chamber that he now holdith and occupieth within my ſaid dwellyng-hows, To have and to hold, to hym duryng the Yeres that I have to come of and in my ſaid Tenement, yf he the ſame William Cony my Broder, ſo long lyve, without any Rent or other Duete to be paid or yolden for the ſame. Alſo, I will thai myn' Executours ſhall every Yere Yerely, duryng the Space of Six Yeres next enſuing my diſceas provide and by oon Lode of Coles, accompting xxiiij Quarters for the Lode, at the price of x s. the Lode, and the ſame Lode Coles ſo bought and provided, I will that the ſame myn' Executours diſtribute and give the ſame to por Houſholders of the ſaid Pariſh of Saint Bennet, and to other next adjoyning the ſame Pariſh within the Ward, that is to ſay, to every Houſholder oon quarter, deſiryng them to pray ſpecially for my Soule and the Soules aforeſaid; and I will that the ſame Coles be given at ſuche tyme of the Yere as it ſhall be thought mooſt convenyent for the nede and comfort of the ſaid por Houſholders. Alſo, I will that my Tenement with th'Appurtenances lying in Ware, in the Countie of Hertford, ſhall be immediatly after my Diſceas ſold by myn' Erecutours to the mooſt profite and advantage. And the ſame Tenement ſo ſold, I will that myn' Executours or the Executours of any of them with the Mony comyng of the ſame ſale, ſhall diſpoſe and give the ſame for my Soule and the Soules above-written, in ſynging of Maſs at Scala coeli Savoy, or Croſſed Freres, Marying of por Maidens, releving of por Priſoners and por Houſholders, amendyng of high, noyous Weyes, and in other good werks of mercy and pity, as the ſame myn Executours or the Erecutours of any of them ſhall think mooſt beſt to the Pleſure of God and helth of my Soule and the Soules aforeſaid. Furthermore, I will that all my Lands and Tenements, Medewes, Leſues and Paſtures, as well Free as Copy, lying and beyng in the Pariſhes of Charlton or Aſhton Combery and Hampton in the Countie of Middl. and elſewhere within the ſame County, Incontinent after my diſceas ſhall wholly remayne to the ſaid Margaret and Johane my Daughters, and to their Heires and Aſſignes for evermore. The reſidue of all my Goods, Catalls and Detts whatſoever they be after my Detts paid and the Coſts of my Burying doon, and this my preſent Teſtament in all things fulfilled wholly, I give and bequethe to the ſaid Margaret my Wif, therewith to do,
ordeyn' and diſpoſe hir free wyll. And of this my preſent Teſtament and laſt Will I make and ordeyn myn' Erecutors, the ſaid Margaret my Wif, and William Cony my Broder: And I bequethe to the ſame William for his labor in the Premiſes, x l. and a Gown Yoven the Day and Yere firſt above-written.
Theſe Witneſs Sir Gerry Coldwel, Curate of the ſaid Chirche, John Porter, Thomas Egerton, William Temple, John Wilſhire, William Cole, John Ruttur and other.
